description: OAPEC embargo on the U.S. and other countries during the Yom Kippur War; triggered a major supply shock and price surge.
source: EIA energy history materials on the 1973–74 embargo; BP Statistical Review historical context

description: Iranian Revolution disrupted oil production and exports, contributing to global supply shortages and price spikes.
source: EIA country/market history and Iran supply disruption context; IEA historical Oil Market Report coverage (1979–1980)

description: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait removed supply and elevated geopolitical risk premiums; prices rose sharply then normalized as supply was restored.
source: EIA chronology/analysis of 1990–91 market impacts; IEA Oil Market Report summaries on supply loss

description: Regional recession reduced oil demand and contributed to a steep decline in oil prices.
source: IMF WEO (1997–1999) on Asia crisis; World Bank East Asia crisis reports relevant to energy demand

description: Coordinated OPEC output cuts helped tighten balances and supported a price recovery after the late-1990s slump.
source: OPEC press releases / Monthly Oil Market Report (1999) quota decisions; EIA analysis of 1999 OPEC cuts and recovery

description: The global financial crisis reduced demand and risk appetite; oil prices fell sharply from 2008 highs to below $40 before recovering.
source: IMF GFSR/WEO (2008–2009); EIA analysis of 2008 oil price collapse; IEA Oil Market Report demand revisions (2008–2009)

event_name: Arab Spring / Libya Civil War Supply Loss
description: Libyan production and exports were severely disrupted, tightening sweet crude supply and raising Brent prices.
source: IEA Oil Market Report (2011) outage estimates; EIA Libya disruption analysis (2011)

description: Rapid growth in U.S. tight oil supply contributed to oversupply; prices fell and volatility remained elevated through 2015–2016.
source: EIA U.S. crude production statistics and 2014–2016 analysis; IEA Oil Market Report on non-OPEC supply growth (2014–2016)

description: OPEC and key non-OPEC producers (including Russia) agreed to coordinated cuts to rebalance the market; compliance reporting shaped expectations.
source: OPEC communications on Nov 30, 2016 agreement and conformity; IEA Oil Market Report on balances (2016–2018)

description: COVID-19 lockdowns reduced travel and fuel consumption; demand collapsed and prices fell sharply (WTI briefly negative; Brent also dropped).
source: IEA Oil Market Report / Global Energy Review (2020); EIA 2020 petroleum market analysis

description: Breakdown of OPEC+ talks contributed to a supply surge and a steep price drop until a new agreement was reached.
source: OPEC meeting outcomes (Mar–Apr 2020); IEA Oil Market Report (Mar–Apr 2020); EIA contemporaneous commentary

description: Record coordinated cuts supported market rebalancing during the pandemic recovery phase.
source: OPEC April 12, 2020 Declaration of Cooperation adjustments; IEA Oil Market Report tracking cuts (2020–2021)

description: War and sanctions reshaped trade flows and increased uncertainty; energy security concerns raised volatility and risk premia.
source: IEA energy security analyses and market updates (2022–2023); EIA analysis of sanctions/trade flows and price impacts

description: Additional voluntary cuts aimed to support prices amid uncertain demand and inventory dynamics; announcements influenced expectations.
source: OPEC press releases on voluntary adjustments (Apr 2023 onward) and MOMR references; IEA Oil Market Report updates (2023–2024)

description: Shipping security incidents and rerouting risks increased freight costs and raised short-run risk premia in energy markets.
source: UNCTAD updates on Red Sea/Suez disruption (2023–2024); IMO security updates; IEA/EIA commentary on freight/risk premia
